msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 147/197

summary.seg: This manuscript of medical treatises was owned by Walter Elveden (d. in or before 1360), a scholar at Cambridge, probably Gonville Hall, who composed a number of astrological works, including tables and an almanac, and a Kalendarium for the years 1330-1386. Elveden later turned his attention to legal studies, compiling an index to papal decrees. He was associated with William Bateman, bishop of Norwich (d. 1355), and accompanied him on a diplomatic mission to the Continent in 1349. At his death in or before 1360, Elveden donated nine of his books, including this one, to Gonville Hall.

The manuscript contains various marginal annotations, including medical recipes and charms in Latin and Middle English. These were added to the manuscript both before and after Elveden owned it. Late 13th- or early 14th-century annotations that occur in both of the manuscript's separate parts indicate that these parts must have been bound together by the time of Elveden's donation.

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Medieval Manuscripts Specialist
Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Numbering in brown ink in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

note.p: Medical recipes in Latin in the margins and empty spaces of pp. 8, 9, 11, 13, 20-21, 22, 49, 50; 98, 99, 100, 102, 103, 106, 152, 153, 160 and Latin charms on pp. 22 ('Tres boni fratres' [wounds]), 65 (Psalm 67:23 ['Scribe for þe mare']), and 74 (Childbirth ['Sancta Maria mater Christi']), by two or more hands from the 15th-century. These medical recipes and charms are also listed in the first and second part of the manuscript.

Medical recipes in Middle English in the margins of pp. 19, 23-25, 35-36, 38, 42, 43-44, 46, 47, 54, 78, 80, 96 [macaronic], 97, 132, by two hands from the late 14th century or early 15th century and 15th century. These recipes have also been listed in the first and second part of the manuscript.
Citation of John 1:6 ('fuit homo missus a deo cui nomen erat') added to p. 15 and p. 115 in a 15th-century hand.
Quire numbers ('1'-'12') added in pencil on the lower right-hand corner of the first rectos of quires, 19th-century.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century panelled brown leather binding with two triple-blind tooled frames.
Binding height: 255 mm; width: 185 mm; depth: 25 mm.

provenance.p: Walter of Elveden (d. in or before 1360), ecclesiastic and astrologer Gualterus Elvedenus, d. in or before 1360, associated with Edmund Gonville and William Bateman, the founders of the Gonville and Caius college: perhaps his donation recorded in a fragmentary inscription on p. 1: 'ex dono magistri Walteri El[ueden]' (for further biographical information, see Hall (2006), pp. 240-241; and Keith Snedegar, 'Walter Eleveden (d. in or before 1360)', Oxford Dictionary of National Bibliography (23 September 2004) [accessed 17 February 2023]). This identification is supported by later additions that indicate that the manuscript circulated in Suffolk. These consist of administrative notes concerning debts and payments in the lower margins of pp. 79 [dated to 5 Henry IV], 112, 127, 131, 149, and 153, including the name of a vicar in Suffolk: 'Johannes Cretyngg', 'Johannes Hevenyngham vic. Suff.', 'Robertus [B]oye', 'Robertus Sparwe', and 'Willelmus Attegap'. The manuscript has also many added medical recipes in Middle English in an East Anglian dialect (see LALME I:63); these annotations indicate that Elveden donated the manuscript as it is, i.e.: its two parts were bound together when he gave it, although the first part already had some annotations made prior to that.

history.acquisition: Acquired by Gonville and Caius College before 1697, in which year the manuscript was recorded as no. 970 in Edward Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliae et Hiberniae in unum collecti, cum indice alphabetico (Oxford: Sheldonian Theatre, 1697). Their armorial bookplate with the classmark '197 - 147' inscribed pasted on the inside of the upper cover (with a reference to the printed catalogue written above it) and the number '147' inscribed at the top on p. 3.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on a description of the manuscript by M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Gonville and Caius College, 2 vols (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1907), I, pp. 166-167.

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 147/197, pp. 1-62

msContents.textLang: Latin texts with added recipes in Middle English

msItem.title: Marginal medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: Medical recipes in Latin in the margins and empty spaces of pp. 8, 9, 11, 13, 20-21, 22, 49, 50 and a Latin charm on pp. 22 ('Tres boni fratres' [wounds]) by two or more hands from the 15th-century; these hands have also added various recipes and charms to the manuscript's second part.

msItem.title: Psalm 6:2
msItem.incipit: 14 Domine ne in furore tuo arguas me neque in ira tua corripias me
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 14th or 15th century. Faded, but legible with UV light.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Medical recipes in Middle English in the margins of pp. 19, 23-25, 35-36, 38, 42, 43-44, 46, 47, 54 by two hands from the late 14th century or early 15th century and 15th century. The same hands have added recipes to the second part of the manuscript.

msItem.title: Note referring to St Denis
msItem.incipit: 23 Item pro domino abbate de sento [sic] dionisio
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 14th or 15th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Medical recipes in Latin in the margins and empty spaces of pp. 23, 24, 44, 49, 55, 57, and 62 in a late 13th- or early 14th-century hand. The same hand has added notes on weights and measures throughout pp. 1-62.

msItem.title: A number verse
msItem.incipit: 62 Bis duo bis ter [tr]ia bis sex bis quatuor [? oua]
msItem.note: Partly legible due to fading of the ink and cropping of the page. Added in the 14th century.

list.item: Quire 54-2 (pp. 59-62: 3rd and 4th leaves after p. 62 excised)

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower right-hand corners of the the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition:
A number of leaves have sustained damage or contain other irregularities:
The first leaf (pp. 1-2) has been mostly torn away, leaving only the upper inside corner.
The outer and upper edges of pp. 3-4 were torn but have been repaired with blank paper.
The leaf that contains pp. 13-14 consists of two halves that have been sewn together with white thread, running vertically between the two columns of text.
The leaf that contains pp. 15-16 has been cut in half lengthways, leaving only the inner half of the leaf.
The leaf that contains pp. 43-44 consists of two half leaves that have been sewn together with blue thread, running vertically between the two columns of text.
There are two parchment stubs after p. 62.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and ine ruling. Written in two columns. 36 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a single hand writing in Northern Gothic Textualis Libraria.
Marginal recipes and charms added by 14th and 15th-century hands writing in Anglicana.

decoNote.p: Two-line initials alternately in blue and red, with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in the opposite colour.

decoDesc.decoNote: Added marginal drawings of a hedgehog or other creature (p. 26); and the head of a horse (x2), ejecting matter from its mouth (p. 37).

origin.origDate: Written in the last quarter of the 13th century or first quarter of the 14th century

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 147/197, pp. 63-174

msContents.textLang: Latin with added recipes in Middle English

msItem.title: Chirurgia
msItem.author: Ruggero Frugardo
msItem.incipit: 63 Post mundi fabricam eiusque decorem de terrestri substancia deus hominem formauit uite
msItem.explicit: 174 a qualitate et quantitate ut de-

msItem.title: Marginal medical recipes and charms
msItem.note: Medical recipes in Latin in the margins and empty spaces of pp. 98, 99, 100, 102, 103, 106, 152, 153, 160 and Latin charms on pp. 65 (Psalm 67:23 with a Middle English heading: 'Scribe for þe mare', and 74 (Childbirth ['Sancta Maria mater Christi']), by two or more hands from the 15th-century; these hands have also added various recipes and charms to the manuscript's first part.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Medical recipes in Middle English in the margins of pp. 78, 80, 96 [macaronic], 97, 132, by two hands from the late 14th century or early 15th century and 15th century. The same hands have added recipes to the first part of the manuscript.

msItem.title: Hymn
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 14th century.

msItem.title: Beginning of a hymn
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 14th century.

msItem.title: Draft indenture (opening words)
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 15th century.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 24 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in Gothica Northern Textualis.
Marginal recipes and charms added by 14th and 15th-century hands writing in Anglicana.

decoNote.p: One large, 9-line initial 'P' in blue with a gold bar along its descender with a white-pink dragon biting into it, and with a miniature inside its loop, showing a tonsured surgeon in a purple robe with a blue garment applying a trephine to the head of a patient in blue clothes and with his hands tied up behind his back.
Two-line and one-line initials alternately in blue and red with penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in the opposite colour.
Headers for sections have been rubricated in red ink.
Line fillers consisting horizontal bars outlined in blue or red ink and with motifs in both colours inside them.

origin.origDate: Written in the second half of the 13th century.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
